content:
=== Game Rules ===
This is vgdl rule file:
BasicGame square_size=32
    SpriteSet
        background > Immovable img=oryx/space1 hidden=True
        base    > Immovable    color=WHITE img=oryx/planet
        avatar  > FlakAvatar   stype=sam img=oryx/spaceship1
        missile > Missile
            sam  > orientation=UP    color=BLUE singleton=True img=oryx/bullet1
            bomb > orientation=DOWN  color=RED  speed=0.5 img=oryx/bullet2
        alien   > Bomber       stype=bomb   prob=0.01  cooldown=3 speed=0.8
            alienGreen > img=oryx/alien3
            alienBlue > img=oryx/alien1
        portal  > invisible=True hidden=True
        	portalSlow  > SpawnPoint   stype=alienBlue  cooldown=16   total=20 img=portal
        	portalFast  > SpawnPoint   stype=alienGreen  cooldown=12   total=20 img=portal

    LevelMapping
        . > background
        0 > background base
        1 > background portalSlow
        2 > background portalFast
        A > background avatar

    TerminationSet
        SpriteCounter      stype=avatar               limit=0 win=False
        MultiSpriteCounter stype1=portal stype2=alien limit=0 win=True

    InteractionSet
        avatar  EOS  > stepBack
        alien   EOS  > turnAround
        missile EOS  > killSprite

        base bomb > killBoth
        base sam > killBoth scoreChange=1

        base   alien > killSprite
        avatar alien > killSprite scoreChange=-1
        avatar bomb  > killSprite scoreChange=-1
        alien  sam   > killSprite scoreChange=2

This is vgdl rule in natural language:
Here’s an analysis in plain language:

1. Game Genre and Theme:
 • It’s a space shooter – very similar in feel to classic arcade “space invader” or “defender” games. You’re piloting a spaceship (the “avatar”) in a cosmic arena filled with enemy aliens and falling projectiles.
 • The art suggests a space and planetary setting (e.g. the “base” is pictured as a planet). The background and other sprites reinforce this outer‐space vibe.

2. Core Mechanics:
 • You control an avatar that can move, and when you hit the edge of the screen (EOS) it “steps back.” This prevents you from leaving the game area.
 • Your ship fires a “sam” projectile— a blue, upward‐moving bullet that you use to hit enemy aliens.
 • Enemies come in the form of aliens that move around the level and drop “bombs” (red, slow-moving downward projectiles) aimed at your base.
 • There are spawn points (portals labeled as “portalSlow” and “portalFast”) that periodically release aliens. Each type (blue and green) has distinct images and possibly slightly different movement speeds.
 • When sprites interact— such as collisions between bullets and aliens, bombs touching the base, or the avatar colliding with enemies— specific outcomes occur (like earning or losing points and killing one or both sprites).

3. Objective and Win/Loss Conditions:
 • The primary goal is to eliminate the invading aliens. The win condition isn’t tied to surviving indefinitely but rather “MultiSpriteCounter stype1=portal stype2=alien limit=0,” meaning you must remove both the spawn portals and any lingering aliens.
 • You lose if your avatar is destroyed (SpriteCounter stype=avatar limit=0 win=False), so keeping your ship intact is essential.
 • Point scoring is also affected by interactions: hitting aliens with your “sam” bullet scores positive points (+2), while touching an alien or bomb with the avatar costs you (-1). Even a collision between your projectile and the base gives a small reward (+1), likely to encourage careful play and precision.

4. Overall Strategy:
 • Defense and Offense in Balance: Stay agile with your avatar, positioning it to dodge enemy aliens and falling bombs while lining up your shots. Avoid direct contact with aliens or bombs to prevent score penalties and avoid losing your ship.
 • Prioritize Eliminating Spawners: Since aliens are generated from two types of portals, a winning strategy is to target and disable these spawn points as early as possible. Clearing the portals means fewer enemies will appear.
 • Precise Shooting: Focus on using your “sam” projectile to hit aliens from a distance. Colliding with them personally might destroy the enemy but at the cost of points, so maintaining distance and letting your projectile do the work is best.
 • Watch for Edge Behavior: Both your ship and the aliens interact with the edge-of-screen boundaries (EOS); your avatar “steps back” when reaching an edge, and aliens “turn around.” Understanding these movements can help you predict enemy paths and manage safe zones.
 • Level Layout Awareness: The level grid includes obstacles or formations (number “0” objects) and an “A” (likely marking an initial position or key location). Use these structures to your advantage by using cover or guiding enemy movement.

Overall, the game challenges you to defend your planetary base by carefully eliminating enemy aliens while managing risks. Stay movement-savvy, be precise with your shooting, and always keep an eye on both the spawning sources and projectiles to secure a win.

You are an intelligent player playing a video game, and you have a friend provide you strategy. Interpret the state, rule, strategy and act accordingly. Notice that your avatar position is one of the most important information, if the position doesn't change from the last state, you need to analyze the state and make a different action from the last time.

=== Available Actions ===
0: ACTION_NIL
1: ACTION_USE
2: ACTION_LEFT
3: ACTION_RIGHT

=== Important Mechanics Notice ===
 In some games, directional actions (LEFT, RIGHT, UP, DOWN) may first cause the avatar to rotate toward the intended direction without immediately moving. If the avatar's position does not change after a directional action, it may indicate a rotation has occurred. To proceed, you must apply the directional action again after rotation. Always verify whether the avatar actually moved after each action. Please understand the rule and the interaction set first, then locate the item, finally choose a meaningful action towards the win and respond in the format: ``` Action:<action number> ```. Include one sentence of feedback on the action and your expectation to see if it aligns with the strategy. Notice, Action 0 will not reasult in any change in this game environment, and you may need to understand the level layout first to play the game. 

=== Sprite Mapping ===
avatar -> 'a'
background -> '.'
background base -> '0'
background portalSlow -> '1'
background portalFast -> '2'
alienGreen -> '@'
base -> '#'
sam -> '$'
alienGreen bomb -> '%'
bomb -> '&'
bomb sam -> '*'

Action:2

I'm moving left to reposition the avatar, hoping to get out of the direct line of the incoming alien fire while keeping a clear shot with the upward sam bullet already in play.
